original: Milindapañha🔽Meṇḍakapañha
analyzed: milindapañha  meṇḍakapañha
translated: The Questions of King Milinda

original: Paṇāmitavagga
analyzed: paṇāmita vagga
translated: The Questions of Menander

original: 9. Aggaggasamaṇapañha🔽“Bhante nāgasena, bhāsitampetaṁ bhagavatā—🔽‘āsavānaṁ khayā samaṇo hotī’ti.
analyzed: aggagga samaṇa pañha  bhante nāgasena bhāsitam petam bhagavatā  āsavānam khayā samaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: The Chapter about the One Sent Away🔽The Questions of the Foremost Ascetic

original: Puna ca bhaṇitaṁ—🔽‘Catubbhi dhammehi samaṅgibhūtaṁ,
analyzed: punar ca bhaṇita  catubbhi dhammehi samaṅgi bhūta
translated: “Though the Blessed One said, ‘One becomes an ascetic by the destruction of the corruptions,’ he also said,

original: Taṁ ve naraṁ samaṇaṁ āhu loke’ti.
analyzed: tam ve naram samaṇam āhu loka iti
translated: ‘One who is endowed with four properties is called an ascetic in the world.’

original: Tatrime cattāro dhammā khanti appāhāratā rativippahānaṁ ākiñcaññaṁ.
analyzed: tatra ime cattāro dhammā khanti appāhāra tā rati vippahānam ākiñcañña
translated: Now these four properties are patience, fewness of wishes, contentment, and aloofness.

original: Sabbāni panetāni aparikkhīṇāsavassa sakilesasseva honti.🔽Yadi, bhante nāgasena, āsavānaṁ khayā samaṇo hoti, tena hi ‘catubbhi dhammehi samaṅgibhūtaṁ, taṁ ve naraṁ samaṇaṁ āhu loke’ti yaṁ vacanaṁ, taṁ micchā.
analyzed: sabbāni pana etāni aparikkhīṇa āsavassa sa kilesassa iva honti  yadi bhante nāgasenaḥ āsavānam khayā samaṇaḥ hoti tena hi catubbhi dhammehi tam ve naram samaṇam āhu loka iti yam tam micchā
translated: But all these are found in one who has not destroyed the corruptions and who is still subject to them.🔽If one becomes an ascetic by the destruction of the corruptions, then the statement that ‘One who is endowed with four properties is called an ascetic in the world’ is wrong.

original: Yadi catubbhi dhammehi samaṅgibhūto samaṇo hoti, tena hi ‘āsavānaṁ khayā samaṇo hotī’ti tampi vacanaṁ micchā, ayampi ubhato koṭiko pañho tavānuppatto, so tayā nibbāhitabbo”ti.
analyzed: yadi catubbhi dhammehi samaṅgi bhūtaḥ samaṇaḥ hoti tena hi āsavānam khayā samaṇaḥ hoti iti tam pi vacanam micchā ayam pi ubhatas koṭikaḥ pañho tava anuppatto saḥ tayā nibbāhitabbaḥ ti
translated: If one becomes an ascetic by being endowed with four properties, then the statement that ‘One becomes an ascetic by the destruction of the corruptions’ is wrong. Here is a double-pronged question now being put to you and you must answer it.”

original: “Bhāsitampetaṁ, mahārāja, bhagavatā ‘āsavānaṁ khayā samaṇo hotī’ti.
analyzed: mahā rāja bhagavatā khayā samaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: “This has been said, sire, by the Blessed One: ‘By the destruction of the cankers one becomes a recluse.’

original: Puna ca bhaṇitaṁ—
analyzed: punar ca bhaṇita
translated: But again it is said:

original: ‘catubbhi dhammehi samaṅgibhūtaṁ, taṁ ve naraṁ samaṇaṁ āhu loke’ti.
analyzed: catubbhi dhammehi samaṅgi bhūta tam ve naram samaṇam āhu loka iti
translated: ‘He who is endowed with four things is called a recluse in the world.’

original: Tadidaṁ, mahārāja, vacanaṁ tesaṁ tesaṁ puggalānaṁ guṇavasena bhaṇitaṁ—
analyzed: tat idam mahā rāja vacanam tesam tesam puggalānam guṇa vasena bhaṇita
translated: This, sire, has been said by the Blessed One in reference to the qualities of various individuals.

original: ‘catubbhi dhammehi samaṅgibhūtaṁ, taṁ ve naraṁ samaṇaṁ āhu loke’ti, idaṁ pana niravasesavacanaṁ ‘āsavānaṁ khayā samaṇo hotī’ti.
analyzed: catubbhi dhammehi tam ve naram samaṇam āhu loke iti idam pana niravasesa vacanam āsavānam khayā samaṇaḥ hoti iti
translated: ‘He who is endowed with four things is called a recluse in the world’—this is a statement without exception: ‘By the destruction of the cankers one becomes a recluse.’

original: Api ca, mahārāja, ye keci kilesūpasamāya paṭipannā, te sabbe upādāyupādāya samaṇo khīṇāsavo aggamakkhāyati.
analyzed: api ca mahā rāja ye keci kilesu upasamāya paṭipannā te sabbe upādāya upādāya samaṇaḥ khīṇāsavaḥ aggam akkhāyati
translated: Moreover, sire, all those who are practising for the sake of the cessation of the defilements, they all, by reason of their clinging, are called recluses, but the one who has destroyed the cankers is called the chief recluse.

original: Yathā, mahārāja, yāni kānici jalajathalajapupphāni, vassikaṁ tesaṁ aggamakkhāyati,
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja yāni kānici jala ja thala ja pupphāni vassikam tesam aggam akkhāyati
translated: As, sire, of all the water-born and land-born flowers the jasmine is considered the chief,

original: avasesāni yāni kānici vividhāni pupphajātāni, sabbāni tāni pupphāniyeva, upādāyupādāya
analyzed: avasesāni yāni kānici vividhāni puppha jātāni sabbāni tāni pupphāniyā iva upādāya upādāya
translated: and all the various kinds of flowers are flowers, by reason of their clinging,

original: pana vassikaṁyeva pupphaṁ janassa patthitaṁ pihayitaṁ;
analyzed: pana vassikayā iva puppham janassa patthitam
translated: but the jasmine is the one that is desired and longed for by people;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, ye keci kilesūpasamāya paṭipannā, te sabbe upādāyupādāya samaṇo khīṇāsavo aggamakkhāyati.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja ye keci kilesu upasamāya paṭipannā te sabbe upādāya upādāya samaṇaḥ khīṇāsavaḥ aggam akkhāyati
translated: Even so, sire, the monk whose cankers are destroyed is declared the chief of all those who are practising for the purpose of allaying the defilements.

original: Yathā vā pana, mahārāja, sabbadhaññānaṁ sāli aggamakkhāyati, yā kāci avasesā vividhā dhaññajātiyo, tā sabbā upādāyupādāya bhojanāni sarīrayāpanāya, sāliyeva tesaṁ aggamakkhāyati;
analyzed: yathā vā pana mahā rāja sabba dhaññānam sāli aggam akkhāyati yā kāci avasesāḥ vividhāḥ dhañña jātiyo tā sabbā upādāya upādāya bhojanāni sarīra yāpanāya sāliyā iva tesam aggam akkhāyati
translated: Or, sire, just as rice is declared the chief of all the grains, and all the other various kinds of grain are declared the chief of all the other kinds of food for the support of the body,

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, ye keci kilesūpasamāya paṭipannā, te sabbe upādāyupādāya samaṇo khīṇāsavo aggamakkhāyatī”ti.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja ye keci kilesu upasamāya paṭipannā te sabbe upādāya upādāya samaṇaḥ khīṇāsavaḥ aggam akkhāyati iti
translated: even so, sire, the monk whose cankers are destroyed is declared the chief of all those who are practising for the purpose of allaying the defilements.”

original: “Sādhu, bhante nāgasena, evametaṁ tathā sampaṭicchāmī”ti.
analyzed: sādhu bhante nāgasena evam etam tathā sampaṭicchāmi iti
translated: “It is good, revered Nāgasena, so it is, therefore do I accept it.”

original: Aggaggasamaṇapañho navamo.
analyzed: aggaggasamaṇapañhaḥ navamaḥ
translated: The ninth chapter.
